Author: Manny Medina
Post Text: Lately, I have been shocked by the number of rookie mistakes I see in sales cycles.Mistakes like sending a pricing proposal over email without scheduling a meeting to review it first and get feedback, being single-threaded, needing to understand the paper process, and being selected vendor of choice without an agreement to make a decision.That‚Äôs just last week!One effect of the last 10 years and ZIRP is that ‚Äútenured‚Äù AEs, ie AEs with 5+ years of experience haven‚Äôt sold in complex selling environments.¬†So even though these AEs are ‚Äúexperienced,‚Äù they don‚Äôt possess the mindset and skillset to sell in today‚Äôs environment.They sold at a time when- Everyone wanted to buy innovation- We didn‚Äôt need to advocate change, build consensus, and show value- Cool technology was enough- Being threaded was ok b/c pretty much anyone in the org could sign a $90K contract- If we didn‚Äôt work our pipeline, inbound leads would make up the restWe are now in a complex environment in which very few AEs are ready- Decision-making needs to be more clear- Shiny products alone don‚Äôt win the deal- Organizations may be making decisions out of fear, not opportunity. The old ‚Äúno one gets fired for buying¬†‚Ä¶‚Äù is back!And this is happening while the budgets for enablement and training are getting cut. So the burden of taking an AE who is experienced but new to this game falls on the manager.What is a Front-Line Manager to do?First, we all need to take work off their plate. Preparing decks for the forecast call or prep meetings needs to go. Forecasting should be automated, done by the AI, and only edited by the manager. If you are asking FLMs to enter forecast numbers manually, they are humoring you and not coaching their team.Second, stop asking the managers to aggregate reports from the 10 tools their reps need to use to do their work. Get a single platform where the reps can do the work and the manager can get the details of the activity, pipeline, and forecast.Third, use your CI tool as your day-to-day enablement tool. Whether you use the latest AI technology with real-time CI that enables the rep to be in the moment with live content cards (yes, like Kaia), or you use the more classic CI recordings, make time to ensure your reps are either listening to the recordings or learning from the live experience. No one has time to take reps off the field for long enablement sessions.Most organizations have a good playbook already. Review your playbook regularly with the team and share stories on how it helped in deals.These will empower the manager to spend more time with their reps teaching them the ropes and setting them up for success.What other tips do you have for FLMs to make more time for coaching their reps?‚ÄúI done seen people f*#k up the whole team 'cause they couldn't play their position‚Äù - Big Sean

Post Text: As CEO of Outreach, I see first-hand how AI unlocks the productivity of our customers' sales teams. But, we haven‚Äôt seen a definitive study measuring the impact of AI on sales teams.... until now. The Marshall School of Business, University of Southern California recently published a report called ‚ÄùWhen and How Artificial Intelligence Augments Employee Creativity‚Äù in which they conducted a field experiment at a telemarketing company, and quantified the impact AI has on their success. To summarize the key findings (full link to full paper in comments):- On average, sales agents with AI assistance were 2.33 times as successful in answering questions they were not previously trained for and thus had to generate answers as their counterparts that did not have AI assistance. - The magnitude of this increase was even more pronounced for top sales agents‚Äî2.81 times that of bottom agents. This increased success in answering untrained questions is critical for AI-assisted agents to achieve higher customer purchase rates than those obtained independently.- The report also found that AI saves sales agents time and energy, enabling highly skilled agents to generate new answers to untrained questions and/or improve existing answers to trained questions, thus demonstrating greater creativity at work. Highly skilled agents also reported feeling ‚Äúelated‚Äù because this changed work mode significantly helps and improves their work.- The report also found that this change in work mode results in a better mood, increased morale, and greater passion for highly skilled agents, all of which are conducive to workplace creativity. The implications of this report are significant for the future of sales. AI can be a powerful tool for driving productivity and innovation when implemented thoughtfully and strategically.At Outreach, Live AI is embedded at the core of our Sales Execution Platform, helping salespeople create and close more pipeline - in the moment! How is your team leveraging AI in Sales? Are you seeing the same benefits as the study? #ai #sales

Author: Manny Medina
Post Text: About once per month I sit down with our SDRs for lunchA question that comes up often is: how do you overcome the objection: ‚ÄúI am too busy to talk to you‚ÄùOr I don‚Äôt have time for you. Or Not right now. I don‚Äôt have a silver bullet. Only lead ones :) If you are in sales, you are going to get hung up on.¬† If you are not getting hung up on, you are not in sales, you are order taking and your job will be replaced. Getting a lot of No‚Äôs is part of the job.The question stand‚Äôs. How do you deal with it?One of the concepts I rely on is pattern interrupting.¬† See, when someone answers a cold call they go into a practiced behaviour of turning the caller down and expecting pushback. It‚Äôs compulsory b/c most cold calls are bad. It‚Äôs automatic. Most people don‚Äôt even think about it. The brain is trained to recognize a situation and go into a pattern.¬† Patterns or behaviour are more efficient than thinking - it consumes less energy.So to win in this game you need to interrupt that pattern. So what do I do? I agree with the person I am calling! ‚ÄúOf course you are too busy, that‚Äôs why I called‚Äù This is an unexpected answer.¬† Most cold callers will try to argue that what they have to say is important and they should stay on the phone. To break the pattern. Agree that they are too busy - and then say - ‚Äúthat‚Äôs why I would love to book time this Thursday at 3 pm when you are less busy and have time for a quick 15 min conversation about trends in your industry‚ÄùThat will elicit either a ‚Äúthat works‚Äù or a ‚Äúhow about 4 pm‚ÄùEither way you win. Confirm what email to use to book the appointment, and Voila! Happy selling. ‚ÄúFollow these rules, you'll have mad bread to break up‚Äù - The Notorious B.I.G.

Author: Manny Medina
Post Text: I get asked why we built a live AI assistant for meetings, Kaia?¬† Like everything else at Outreach, it all started with our own pain. By the time we wrote the first line of code for Kaia, we had tried all other Conversational Intelligence solutions, from the loud ones you hear about all the time to the ones that are not as popular. We found all of them lacking. These were my issues - my team had others - these are mine:First, adoption. All vendors¬†asked us to go wall-to-wall to facilitate ‚Äúsharing‚Äù. But then adoption was not great. When it was all said and done, only about 20% to 30% of the AEs and managers were using it.¬† Second, effectiveness. For CI to be effective, a sales manager had to listen to the most of the calls to pick up the nuggets of brilliance or the coaching opportunities. ‚ÄúYou know what I need? I need one more thing to do‚Äù said no sales manager ever. Matter of fact, most of them are overwhelmed, under-resourced, jumping from deal to deal, and trying to stay on top of their 1-1s.¬†So very few of them actually used recording to coach or listen to calls to begin with. Third, automation. For being built in the last decade, CI lacked real AI, or the I in CI. If you want to track important moments in the call, you have to manually enter them. To score a call, you have to enter the keywords you are looking for and then - wait for it - go back to the call and manually score it. Ain‚Äôt nobody got time for that.All these issues really bothered me. A great sales solution, solves problems, not creates more work. There had to be a better way. Out of nowhere came Abhi¬†Abhishek into my life. He had a vision for a real time meeting and conversational AI that would be like having an assistant - always present, smart, and ready to help. To get this AI assistant to work and be helpful during the meeting - not just after, we had to invent a new technology:¬† Custom AIs. Kaia generates an AI assistant that is fine tuned based on your context, so that it‚Äôs accurate in its recommendations and specific to your buyer.And now with LLMs, this Custom AI extends to all areas of Outreach and your sales cycle. It shows up in your Mutual Action plan, in your forecast, in your deal health, and in your pipeline health, and soon in your sequences, templates, and emails. Why? Because sales is a unified cycle, not a patchwork of activities!¬† The investment in AI paid off. Kaia has 70% adoption and managers can at-a-glance see a summary of what‚Äôs happening in a deal and intervene only when needed. No one needs to meet to figure out how a deal is doing or how if your quarter is doing - that is 8 hours a week per rep! More if you are in rev ops!¬† And with our Scoring and Guided Selling release coming up (Oops I spilled the beans) we are taking it to the next level. AI will not only score your calls but it will help you DURING the call to make sure you hit the highest, every time! ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt know, now you know‚Äù¬† - Biggie

Author: Manny Medina
Post Text: Ahead of this week‚Äôs earnings releases, I talked to a friend of mine, a founder and CEO of a public company about the tone at board meetings during FY24 planning.We compared notesAll conversations at the board are a version of this: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the catalyst for us to get back to growth?‚Äù which is euphemism for ‚ÄúWhen is this sh*t going to be over?‚ÄùThe real answer is, ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt know‚Äù. We are CEOs, not fortune-tellers.¬† The answer isn‚Äôt ‚Äúwe are never going back‚Äù or ‚Äúmid-next year.‚Äù We just don‚Äôt know. No one does. It would be disingenuous to say otherwise. The bottom hasn‚Äôt fallen out of tech yet. And now other sectors are being cautious, which creates extra friction in the sales cycle.This CEO and I talked about what we can control in the meantime. We can all agree that despite the turbulence and the unevenness in performance, we have a business inside our business that is a gem. A business that solves a problem for someone.¬† A strong market fit, even if the market it serves is under pressure or contracting. It may be a smaller business, but it‚Äôs a great business. A business that is delivering substantial value for customers and is worth a lot.¬† It has a strong team behind it, a remarkable product, and more predictable cash flow. This business is not obvious in the overall numbers for several reasons: we sold to the wrong early customers, churn and contraction, stalled deals, delayed collections, etc. it could be many things.But the truth is, that inside your business, there is a great business.¬† The question is, how do we pay more attention to this part of the business? Track it, focus on it, invest in it. And maybe deprioritize the rest. This is hard as it means saying no to good ideas, but the only way forward is through ruthless prioritization.Now is not the time to have 5 different strategies and see which one pays off. You need one strong strategy that has a great fit in the market that you can grow even in these times - even if slowly. Save those strategies for another time. They aren‚Äôt going anywhere, and the faster you prioritize your core business, the sooner you can get back to more experimental strategies.That‚Äôs what this CEO and I concluded was the best path forward. ‚ÄúWhen obstacles arise, you change your direction to reach your goal; you do not change your decision to get there.‚Äù Zig Ziglar

Author: Manny Medina
Post Text: On his first day, I met Stephen Oommen, Outreach's new VP of Sales for the Enterprise and Strategic segments, and he dropped some of the best hiring advice. Here it is#1 Hire people who have a burning desire to succeed Like most things, this advice is simple and hard to do. And more importantly, it's really hard to copy.There are a lot of people who want to succeed - but don't want it badly enough, i.e., they don‚Äôt have a plan, don‚Äôt set goals, and are not up to making the sacrifices that it takes to succeed as an AE.It‚Äôs really hard to motivate people. You can help people find their greatness, but at the end of the day, people will need to want to be excellent and motivate themselves. It's far easier to find someone with a burning passion and desire to succeed and elevate their game.As Jim Rohn said. ‚ÄúDon't take ducks to eagle school.‚Äù#2 Hire SlowStephen reminded me of Price‚Äôs law and taught me how it applies to sales. Price‚Äôs law says that 50% of the work is done by the square root of the total number of people who participate in the work.Think about that.¬† Even if you have all the intentions of building a high-performing sales organization, you already have a law working against you!How do you beat Price‚Äôs law? To beat this law, you have to be incredibly judicious and deliberate in your hiring. You don't ‚Äúscale‚Äù teams. This is hard. There is a lot of talent out there, and we need that production!¬† But take your time hiring, especially in a role as important as Ent or Strat AE. Enterprise reps are incredibly impactful. A deal brought in by an enterprise rep can change the company's direction.¬† But they can also sit on payroll and consume lots of cash. So a mistake here is costly.Doctor Jordan Peterson said, ‚ÄúAs your company grows, incompetence grows exponentially, and competence grows linearly.‚Äù So take your time assembling a high-performing group of players. Hold an uncomfortably high bar on excellence in performance and fix mistakes quickly.What‚Äôs your advice for building high-performing sales teams? ‚ÄúI got hustle though, ambition, flow inside my DNA‚Äù- Kendrick Lamar

Author: Manny Medina
Post Text: I‚Äôve been comparing notes with investors about the meaning of the Clearbit acquisition by HubSpot and where we are. In times like this, it is good to pause to figure out what is permanent and what will change.The permanent thing is whenever you see a bunch of point solutions in a particular function, you will see consolidation.¬† Why?¬† The cost of the swivel chair tax of going from application to application to do a job will eventually overwhelm the slight benefits you will get from having point solutions.¬† As any function matures and the job becomes more understood, platforms start taking over point solutions.¬† This is what we are seeing in marketing automation.¬† Marketing automation has been around for a long time.¬† The assets you need to drive great marketing automation have also been around for a long time, so now you are seeing what I think is the beginning of a strong consolidation move around not only the platform that does the marketing automation but also the signals that come into the platform.¬† We will see the same things in sales, in that there are too many applications to do too few jobs, anywhere between 5 applications for 3 jobs or 10 applications for 3 jobs.¬† This must be rationalized into a single application to allow the entire Go-To-Market to do a single job.There will be disruptions - especially in #RevOps.¬† While consolidation in the short term is painful, the long-term benefits outweigh the short-term pain.This is exciting, especially for those that have a platform that is ready to go.¬† Once you go down the path of the platform, you can accelerate faster across all functions, making it easier for the end user to do their job, the organization to consume, and for RevOps and Enablement to drive change.

Post Text: People often talk about the challenge of Technical Debt. But what doesn‚Äôt get enough airtime is Organizational Debt. When you‚Äôre early and you‚Äôre growing fast, it‚Äôs natural to add programs and people to help you grow. But you never get a chance to step back and say ‚ÄúIf we were to build our company from scratch today, what would we build? As a product? As an organization?‚ÄùCompany leaders need to build the muscle of asking themselves this question regularly.¬†¬†¬†Every time you go through a planning cycle, you need to assign 20% of your resources to looking at what got you where you are today, and determine what‚Äôs not going to serve you as you go forward. Another useful tool to rethink your organization is zero-based budgeting. But budgeting is just the outcome. What‚Äôs useful here is to rethink your people, organization, and processes. What‚Äôs required is for leaders to regularly rethink their entire organization - so that you can execute on strategy moving forward! And this is the most important thing - the organization needs to serve the forward strategy, not what worked in the past!Unfortunately, this can‚Äôt be a bottom-up approach, because people will naturally choose incremental changes. To drive real change, you first need top-down direction and then to work from the ground up on implementing that. At Outreach, we‚Äôre 100% focused on our platform strategy. And every quarter we evaluate where we are on that journey to make sure we‚Äôre laser-focused on executing on that strategy.How do you overcome organizational debt?

Post Text: Over the next 12 days I will be sharing some prospecting advice I have picked up along the way from working with the best in the business.Let‚Äôs start with Account research.Before we get into it, the most important thing to understand about account research is that research is not prospecting and doesn‚Äôt build pipeline.Prospecting is prospecting.So make sure you time-bound your research step and do it on a separate times that are not your call blocks or your Pipeline Generation Time - PGT. PGT is sacred and you should reserve your best hours of the days and best days of the week for that activity.And because PGTs are sacred, you need to come prepared. Account research is how we get ready for a great PGT session.The two goals of Account research are:- Become an expert in the industry and account so that you can be a trusted adviser- Develop your account strategyTo be a trusted adviser you need to bring advice. Advice helps open up a cold call or any conversation with an offer to share something new and important about your prospect‚Äôs industry. The winning opening are those with an insight about your prospect‚Äôs industry that your prospect was not expecting and will benefit from it.You can only do that if you understand the market, use their terminology, and trends.If you are prospecting into public companies you have a treasure trove of data and earnings reports (stick to 10Ks) that tell you exactly what the company cares about. For private companies look at their press releases to see the narrative they are putting out into the world. Spend time on their blog. Do more than just reading the homepage.¬† Go deep.¬† If they are in tech use layoffs.fyi to get a sense of how they are doing.Use this information to create a point of view on your prospect‚Äôs industry.¬† Come up with a few hypotheses of what‚Äôs important. Write them down. And then test them in cold calls. The ones that get you a meeting are the winners.Here is the step no one does.Record yourself opening up a cold call and delivering that advice.¬† Most of us have never listened to ourselves talk, so we don‚Äôt know what we sound like.¬† Most of us do not use the right pauses and tone in our voice to ask a question.The first time you do it you will not like what you hear. And that‚Äôs the point.Your job after doing all this research is to sound confident and calm in a cold call or a first meeting. If you don't, all this work is a waste.So practice!Practice your intonation. Your pauses. Practice your responses to challenges. Practice sounding confident and calm.People can tell when you are confident and know what you are talking about from your tone of voice. So make sure you have this covered.Next up, prospect research‚ÄúGetting paid is her forteEach and every day, true player way‚Äù - Blackstreet

Post Text: #WorkflowEvolutionThe #NoDecisionEpidemic is contagious, and it‚Äôs already made itself comfortable in your workflows. This was a major topic of discussion at Outreach‚Äôs GTM KO. One of the causes of both new logo CAC and expansion costs going up is what I call the ‚ÄúNo Decision‚Äù Epidemic. It makes the new logo problem even more infuriating, when you see the number of deals going to ‚ÄúNo Decision‚Äù climbingI have two ideas on why this is happening. One you can control and one you can‚Äôt.Let‚Äôs start with the one you can‚Äôt control:The market for mid and small size tech companies hasn't quite turned around yet. Most large companies are buying from the large software players because they‚Äôre playing it safe! So, smaller companies (us included) are having a harder time getting customers to a decision. In addition to that, if you‚Äôve read books like the Jolt Effect, you know that even if you are the selected vendor of choice, there is still inherent risk of indecision when it comes to moving forward.In this environment, you need to move a deal forward in micro-commitments and build on each other and build momentum towards a close. Post Text: Let‚Äôs talk about prospecting. You are prepared. You made your list of contacts.¬†You know the company you're prospecting.¬†You know a lot about each prospect you are about to call. You already sent them a few articles about their industry with some trends and predictions. They already know who you are.You practiced your opening line. Your first five seconds. And because you shared relevant information with your prospect, which you are about to share on this call, your confidence level is up.¬† You did your research, and you are ready to go! The goal: get your prospects to give you 30 minutes to share what you have learned from talking to other executives in your prospects industry. Easy? No. Terrifying? Yes.One of our biggest fears - after public speaking - is the fear of rejection. ¬† And you will get rejected.Rejections will not roll off your back. Irrespective of what everyone else says. When you are cold calling, you are not in control, and rejection will attack our basic human need to feel accepted. In short, it will hurt.No easy way to recover. Some people will be outright rude and make you mad. Some will lower your self-esteem and will make you second-guess yourself. ¬†Here are a few tips on how to get over the first few knocks. Don't take it personally. Imagine your prospect having a bad day. After getting rejected, take a¬† break and spend a minute feeling empathy for your prospect. Then, move on to your next call. Work with a buddy. Nothing like having someone else go through the same experience to validate what you are going through. It‚Äôs far easier to process rejection by talking through it out loud with someone else. Get into a state of gratitude. It‚Äôs hard to be thankful and upset at the same time. Try it. After getting rejected, spend a few minutes being thankful for what you have and get yourself to a state of gratitude that will help you prepare for the next call.Or un-training.¬† Funny story: I participated in a dial power hour with my team in London, reaching out to European prospects in Europe. The names of the people I was calling didn't come easy to me, and out of politeness, I kept starting my calls, repeating the prospects‚Äô full names. It took me a few hang-ups to realize that no one opens a conversation like that. I felt stupid. My SDR colleagues looked at me with a smile; we all laughed a little and got back to calling. In your journal, document the rejections, objections, brush-offs, and any other reflective negative responses. In your quiet time, come up with great answers for each. There is only a finite number of ways people can tell you ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù¬† After a few weeks, you will see that these rejections will start sounding the same. This means that you can start planning your answers in advance.Start winning more often, regain your confidence, get your confidence back, and start booking meetings. ‚ÄúYou just remain asCalm as possible,Make the deal go through‚Äù - BiggieOutreach #prospecting #sales

Post Text: #WorkflowEvolutionAt Digital Now, I got to discuss workflow evolution and what it means in the face of AI. There is a lot of AI Noise in the market, and Outreach happens to be part of it. Every company is promoting AI tech but their value isn‚Äôt automatic for revenue teams. In the past, AI had mostly meant pattern recognition and had been used to predict outcomes. Predictive AI has been successfully incorporated into most applications and has become table stakes for modern sales tools, but its insights are not particularly actionable.Generative AI like GPT exploded onto the market with high expectations. This technology can do amazing feats like generate emails and summarize meetings - and that saves a ton of time!.But it doesn‚Äôt elevate sellers or highlight a clear path of action for REVENUE teams after that email has been created or that call summarized. It's a great general administrative AI tool, but it doesn‚Äôt indicate where you are in the customer‚Äôs journey.To incorporate the right AI into your processes, you need a thorough understanding of your workflows. THAT‚ÄôS where AI will elevate and unlock your team‚Äôs full human potential and the power of your workflows.In the future, sales-specific AI will do a number of pieces in the sales process to free the seller and manager to do quintessentially human things like coaching, working the deal, having meaningful conversations, progressing the deal, and deepening commitment. Automation will free up the administrative headache so sales people can do what they do best: sell.How AI can improve sales workflows:¬†- Predictive AI understands what could happen next and provides the next best actions to reduce the probability of a bad outcome (like an objection or a no show) and improve the probability of a good one, like next steps.¬†- Generative AI allows us to enhance the human to human communications and to do the mundane and manual work for the seller - like giving live guidance during calls and meetings, summarizing calls and auto generating post call coaching, and following-up with prospects or customers.The more complex the situation, the more AI can help sellers to drive workflows. Now, sellers are free to focus on the core job of selling, of being change agents, and really being trusted advisors and buyers‚Äô agents to their customers. Free or generic AI solutions in a GPT wrapper will likely not be the answer, you‚Äôll need an AI partner that is specific to your processes. Obviously, I recommend Outreach, but as you explore your workflows and the AI landscape, the RIGHT AI solution is what will make the difference.Workflow isn‚Äôt just another fancy buzzword you should adopt because it is trendy, they are the path forward for revenue organizations to be profitable. Workflows are the baseline for your 1-year, 3-year, 5-year sales strategies and the earlier you establish them the better. Outreach is here to be your tool AND trusted advisor throughout your revenue journey.

Post Text: Last time we talked about account research as the way to become a trusted advisor and develop¬† your account strategy. Next is prospect research. But first, a PSA. Prospect research is NOT prospecting and doesn‚Äôt build pipeline. Prospecting is the only way to build pipeline. Prospect research prepares you for a great prospecting session.Selling is the art of leading change. Most change is against the status quo. As a matter of fact, in every sales organization I have researched, over 50% of their close-losts are to No Decision. Prospect research is about figuring out your plan of attack to drive change. The goal is a change from the status quo to your solution. Most people in sales have been taught to find a decision-maker and reach out to them. That‚Äôs wrong. There is no such thing as a decision maker but a group of people who surround the decision maker who can‚Äôt agree with what the problem is, a desired end state, or who the right partner is to solve the problem.¬† The first step to drive change is to build a coalition of believers inside the account.So this is what we need to get done to identify everyone involved: - Understand who are the decision makers and decision shapers- Understand their motivations- What do they know? What do they believe is true?- How do you change that perception?There are lots of public sources to get you well down the journey. Referencing their LinkedIn profile is a start, but the pros go deeper. They re-read posts to see what the prospect takes the time to post or comment on. They see if the prospect posts on X (unlikely by now). Look at their company job postings - those are the company bets. Look what their CEOs are saying publicly. For extra points, call people formerly in the function at the company you are selling to and have moved on to a different company. They will give you time - people love to talk, and no one does this! As Zig Ziglar said, there are no traffic jams on the extra mile.¬† This is where most sellers go wrong. Prospecting research and prospecting is continuous throughout the deal cycle. It doesn‚Äôt end when you open an opportunity. And as you get closer to a decision, decision shapers will come out of the woodwork. The more important your deal the more people will attach themselves to that decision. Be ready. Don‚Äôt ignore them. Most companies just need one No for your deal to stall or die. Understand who they are, their motivations, and how to get them to believe in you and your solution.In this new world of sales where AEs are expected to generate 50% of their own pipeline, prospect research becomes your superpower. The better and faster you are at this the higher your efficiency at generating income from cold accounts. Guarantee a million sales, call it level up - Mase
